column1: #SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	0	Are the five separate pieces of financial emergency measures in the public interest legislation that are on the Statute Book from 2009 to 2013
column2: which were necessary when introduced
column3: currently justified
column4: and has the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform plans for a phased repeal of this legislation?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	1	The Deputy will be aware that there are two measures that currently underpin public service pay and pensions policy: the Financial Emergency Measures in the Public Interest
column2: FEMPI
column3: Acts and the Haddington Road agreement. The nature of the financial emergency measures is that the powers granted by the Oireachtas under the legislation are temporary in nature and predicated on the continuing financial emergency in the State. The Haddington Road agreement is due to last for three years from 1 July 2013. As provided for under section 12 of the FEMPI Act 2013
column4: I am required to annually review the Acts
column5: and a written report of my findings is laid before each House of the Oireachtas. My last review was laid before the Houses of the Oireachtas on 29 June 2014. In that review I concluded that there is still a need to continue to apply the relevant provisions of the legislation controlling the cost of remuneration of public servants and the other measures controlling the cost of the public service pay and pensions bill. It is worth restating that the expenditure proposals as set out in budget 2015 are based
column6: in part
column7: on the reduced public service pay bill
column8: as well as on the revenue accruing from the pension-related deduction and public service pension reduction as provided for under the FEMPI Acts. As well as the statutory requirement for an annual report to be made by me as Minister on the operation of the Acts
column9: the legislation is maintained under constant review. The Deputy will be aware that the Government has recently accepted my proposal for the deletion of section 2B of the 2013 Act. As the powers provided to me under that Act have not been exercised to date and are not now necessary
column10: I have proposed that they should be deleted from the legislation
column11: and proposals on that matter will be before this House shortly. The Haddington Road agreement
column12: in the Government's view
column13: sets the parameters for pay policy in the public service for a three-year time horizon. The agreement has enabled a key reduction in public service pay and pensions. The cost reductions and productivity increases - the reform dividend that we discussed on the last occasion - has allowed the Government the scope to recruit additional staff to key front-line services. This demonstrates that the agreement is delivering
column14: that it has achieved its negotiated purpose and that it continues to be of value.

column1: Additional information not given on the floor of the House
As the country moves
column2: thankfully
column3: into a more normal pay-setting environment
column4: a change we can already see is under way in the private sector
column5: I believe it is important that I
column6: as Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform
column7: give consideration to how
column8: over the medium term
column9: pay policy needs to develop in the public service to help ensure that overall fiscal targets
column10: including the achievement of a deficit of less than 3% of GDP by the end of 2015
column11: will be met. In addition
column12: the public service unions have indicated their intention
column13: should the State's financial circumstances permit
column14: to lodge a pay claim next year. If such a claim is made
column15: the Government will of course have to consider it in line with the prevailing fiscal position. The legal position concerning the financial emergency legislation
column16: which has underpinned the reductions to date
column17: will also have to be addressed as part of the establishment of more normal pay-setting arrangements in the public service for the future.  When my consideration is more advanced
column18: I will bring proposals to the Government in the first instance. Any proposals to amend the FEMPI Acts will require primary legislation to be brought before the Oireachtas.

column1: #SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	2	The Minister has summarised the current position without giving any reason as to why he is holding the current position. He said he issued his report on 29 June 2014 in respect of the annual review of the need for the FEMPI legislation and he concluded that it is still necessary
column2: but he gave no explanation as to why he believes it is still necessary. The level of the national debt is now decreasing as a percentage of GDP
column3: and I understand that is the principal reason being used in this respect. Given that things are moving in the right direction
column4: it is a reason to say that in the near future the legislation will no longer necessary. I note the Minister said that the Haddington Road agreement runs until 2016. There is almost an implication that when we reach the end of that period there might not be any further need for the FEMPI legislation. However
column5: it might be possible during 2015 for the Minister to consider
column6: similarly to the way in which he cut the Croke Park agreement short by six months
column7: going into negotiations and having a new bilateral discussion with public servants in advance of the agreement's coming to its natural end with a view to advancing developments.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	3	There is merit in what the Deputy is saying. It is necessary to maintain the income stream from the reduction of pay that underpins the 2015 budget
column2: and without the FEMPI legislation that budget would not be robust. I am conscious
column3: and I have said this to the House
column4: that the FEMPI legislation is by its nature an emergency
column5: and that is why I have to make a report to the House. The day will come
column6: thankfully
column7: when it will not be possible to assert that the emergency will be maintained; the emergency will be over. I want to prepare for an orderly unwinding of the FEMPI legislation rather than simply drifting into a situation in which somebody could take a court action and the courts could say that there is demonstrably not an emergency to sustain it. I have indicated that I propose to open negotiation with the public sector unions during the course of 2015 to discuss an orderly wind-down of the FEMPI legislation and to discuss the broader horizon of public sector pay as we go forward.

column1: #SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	4	The Minister said he was concerned about the possibility of a court case
column2: and he wants to be able to demonstrate that there is still an emergency and that the legislation is necessary as of now. His actions in government on budget day demonstrated that there is no financial emergency. It is not possible to reconcile tax cuts for the highest earners in Ireland
column3: as was signalled on budget day and as discussed in Finance Bill that has been going through the House yesterday and today
column4: with a financial emergency. The actions of the Government have shown there is no financial emergency. If there was
column5: the Government could not be giving tax cuts to the wealthiest people in Ireland
column6: which is what it is doing in the Finance Bill. The Minister's actions show that he cannot justify his position that there is a financial emergency when the Government is looking after the wealthy and there is talk of the possibility of water subsidies for millionaires in the ether this morning. He has shown that the emergency is over
column7: and he should deal with the legislation.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	5	I thank the Deputy for his warm congratulations on our having solved the existential threat to the Irish people and the economy through the hard work of the Government
column2: supported by the Irish people
column3: in all the hardships they have endured for the past number of years
column4: and for fixing the dreadful mess that had been created. It is a matter to be celebrated that we have made such progress
column5: but we are not out of the woods. That point has been made by both the Minister
column6: Deputy Noonan
column7: and myself. We need to reach the target of a deficit below 3% of GDP next year
column8: and in order to do that
column9: the budgetary arithmetic requires the contribution from the public service through pay reductions that were negotiated and agreed by the public sector unions under the Haddington Road agreement. That will be maintained.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	6	My question is in a similar vein
column2: although it refers specifically to the Minister's proposal to delete section 2B of the FEMPI Act of 2009. As we all know
column3: this gave him unilateral power to cut the pay of public servants and increase their hours. What is the implication of the repeal of that section for the take-home pay of civil service and public sector workers
column4: and what are his plans for further negotiation with public sector trade unions?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	7	I thank the Deputy for the question. The Government has accepted my proposal to amend the Financial Emergency Measures in the Public Interest (No. 2) Act 2009 by the deletion of section 2B
column2: which was inserted into the Act by section 2 of the Financial Emergency Measures in the Public Interest Act 2013. Section 2B provided that existing powers under any other enactment could be exercised to reduce non-basic pay - premium and overtime rates - or increase the working hours of individual public servants. This was a limited contingency measure whose effect was confined to confirming that existing powers to make changes to working time and remuneration rates other than basic pay may be exercised to effect less favourable terms if required to secure necessary savings in the public service pay bill. The provision was regarded as a necessary backstop to enable measures to be taken
column3: in the absence of agreement with employees
column4: to secure the absolutely required savings. As the Deputy will be aware
column5: rather than acting unilaterally to reduce pay as its predecessor did
column6: the Government chose last year to continue to negotiate with public service unions. As a consequence
column7: we were able to reach an acceptable agreement which provided not only a basis for savings in the public service pay and pensions bill of up to an additional €1 billion in the period to 2016
column8: but a way to address all matters relating to working hours and non-basic pay.  The powers provided under this section did not need to be exercised and were not exercised
column9: and the requirement to have the powers on the Statute Book
column10: in my view
column11: has now passed.As I said in my reply to Deputy Sean Fleming
column12: I am committed to keeping the emergency legislation under general review
column13: which is important. Because there is such concern among public servants generally and their representatives about this power it is appropriate to delete it
column14: now that it is no longer required. As regards future negotiations with public service trade unions
column15: I have stated the Government's position is that the Haddington Road agreement will last until 2016. The cost reductions
column16: productivity increases and the reform dividend which allow me to recruit new front-line staff continue. This demonstrates that the agreement is delivering and making a significant contribution to the achievement of the fiscal consolidation target as we work to achieve a deficit below 3% of GDP by 2015.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	8	I welcome the deletion of the measure. At the time it was regarded correctly as a very negative development
column2: not just in terms of the pay and conditions of public service workers but also a real intrusion on the voluntarist system of collective bargaining which had traditionally operated in this jurisdiction. It gave the Minister unilateral powers
column3: which he said he did not use. Of course
column4: he did not have to use them because it was the stick
column5: rather than the carrot
column6: that he used in his dealings with the public sector trade unions. It is very important that the Government now accept that that type of measure
column7: be it an emergency measure or otherwise
column8: was wrong and that it commit to using the traditional form of negotiation and bargaining with the unions. On the issue of pay recovery
column9: the subject of the second part of my question and the one most immediately in people’s minds
column10: is the Minister saying that
column11: notwithstanding the hoopla about the repeal
column12: public service workers will not see any improvement in their pay packets between now and 2016?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	9	I agree with much of what the Deputy said. I am a strong supporter of free collective bargaining. The problem we faced in recent years was a real threat to the viability of the economy and we were required to make savings across all fronts
column2: all of which were challenging and difficult
column3: not least the very large contribution we required the public service to make
column4: as it consumed one third of the total current budget. Public servants stepped up to the plate and voted to accept the Haddington Road agreement. We must now work towards normalising the relationship between public service employers and public servants in normal dialogue. That will happen as we emerge from the crisis. On the impact of the repeal of section 2B
column5: clearly
column6: as it was never invoked
column7: its repeal will not have any monetary impact.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	10	The Minister will recall that at the time he did not invoke the provision as he did not have to do so. Public sector workers felt that
column2: while they were nominally around the table for discussions
column3: in fact
column4: they were on the menu. They felt hugely disempowered. The Minister took an onerous power onto himself. It is welcome that the measure will be repealed and removed from the Statute Book and I hope it will never reappear in any incarnation in the future. There is a difficulty with the issue of pay recovery and I have discussed the matter previously with the Minister. Lower grade public servants and civil servants on lower pay are struggling badly
column5: not unlike others in society and the economy. Whatever is the detail of the repeal of specific mechanisms
column6: the real question for them is when there will be some relief in their pay packets
column7: pockets and households. The Minister is aware that many people who work for the State rely on family income supplement to make ends meet. There is an urgent need to address the matter
column8: starting with the low paid
column9: not with those in the upper echelons
column10: and to set out and agree in a concrete way
column11: rather than in a theoretical way
column12: to the milestones people might expect to see in respect of pay recovery. As the Minister was quick enough to set out milestones for cuts and the damage to people’s income levels
column13: he should set out a positive trajectory in terms of pay recovery.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	11	A number of questions were raised. First
column2: each union voted on the issue. For the first time every single union voted
column3: with the exception of the Irish Hospital Consultants Association
column4: to accept the framework.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	12	It was a case of accept it
column2: or else.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	13	That was in stark contrast with the actions of the previous Government. Public servants understood our capacity to maintain public services was under threat unless we all contributed in the way we had set out. In terms of another section 2B being necessary in the future
column2: I hope it will not. I hope we never again face the type of existential threat to the economy that we faced in steering the ship of State in recent years. Please God
column3: we will never have that level of disaster visited on us again. I strongly agree with the Deputy in her question on low pay. That is the reason the Government has determined to establish a low pay commission that will apply not only to the private sector but also to the public sector. We want to ensure that not only do we restore full employment in the State
column4: which is our objective – yesterday we saw that the unemployment rate was still very high
column5: but it is now 11% and falling – but also that those who are in work have a liveable wage.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	14	In view of the Irish Water fiasco which has continued for many weeks and in view of the fact that the Minister has rightly set out new parameters for the appointment of directors to semi-State bodies and State agencies
column2: I wonder if the Government has a new policy or a new attitude towards quangos. The point of the question is to try to elicit whether there are statistics available to show what has happened during the lifetime of the Government in terms of its commitment to reform quangos.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	15	I thank the Deputy for the question. I am pleased to set out the remarkable achievements we have made in three years. There have been two phases to the rationalisation programme for State bodies
column2: involving two separate tranches of rationalisation measures. As I explained to the House in February when the Deputy last inquired about this matter
column3: the Government made two commitments in 2011 shortly after taking office. The first was to begin immediately implementation of phase one of the rationalisation programme
column4: which involved 48 measures. Each measure had multiple impacts. The second commitment was to review a further 46 measures targeted at broader rationalisation that would constitute phase two. Through implementation of both phases
column5: the Government set two high level targets against which the success of the programme could be measured. As we set out in 2011
column6: the first target was to achieve savings of €20 million for the Exchequer. The second target was to reform this sector of the State system - meaning a less crowded administrative landscape
column7: reduced duplication
column8: greater democratic accountability and clearer lines of responsibility. In overall terms
column9: the latest assessment by my Department
column10: based on information provided
column11: is that measures involving more than 90% of the bodies we set out to have merged
column12: rationalised or abolished have been completed. That means that there are 169 fewer State bodies than when we took office in 2011
column13: with a further 12 yet to be abolished.That is a remarkable achievement in three years. The same analysis shows that Exchequer savings of more than €18 million have been achieved to date
column14: with a further €9 million profiled to come in when the final phase is achieved. That is €27 million in savings to the Exchequer. Of the €18 million already achieved
column15: €15 million is a recurring annual saving accruing
column16: while €3 million is revenue from a once-off property disposal. Of the further €9 million profiled to come in
column17: the Deputy will understand from his own background that
column18: just as in the private sector
column19: some mergers have upfront costs
column20: which is why there is a delay in the additional €9 million coming in. In addition to these figures
column21: the latest assessment suggests net savings of a further €40 million will accrue annually to the local authority sector on foot of the reform and rationalisation measures that have been taken. There is a lot more detail that I will supply to the Deputy
column22: but it has been a remarkable achievement.

column1: Additional information not given on the floor of the House
Regarding the rationalisation programme's second key target of reform
column2: as I have mentioned
column3: as a result of the programme there are 169 fewer State bodies today than there were in 2011. A total of 141 bodies have effectively been abolished and moved into existing public service structures
column4: while 51 old bodies have been streamlined into 23 new bodies. In doing this the Government has tackled duplication and streamlined citizen access and accountability. The Deputy also asks about the newly created bodies. A small number of new bodies have been established in recent years to address urgent matters of concern to the Government such as systematic failings of oversight or a need for new resources to tackle priority issues around job creation and unemployment. For such reasons
column5: the Government has established the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council
column6: the Credit Union Restructuring Board
column7: Microfinance Ireland
column8: the Insolvency Service of Ireland and the Charities Regulatory Authority. There will also be a new policing authority in the near future. These are critical bodies responding to important issues of value to the State and the citizens. It reinforces the point that State bodies play an important and legitimate part in implementing Government policy and delivering public services. What is essential is that this happen in a structured and coherent manner and that their impact and performance are understood
column9: reviewed and managed. To this end
column10: new provisions will be included in an updated code of practice for the governance of State bodies which will be published later this year and ensure a smarter and more targeted use of State bodies into the future.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	16	Certainly
column2: on the surface it appears as though 169 removals of State bodies mark an improvement. It certainly tells us what an awful state the quangos were in before the Government took office and how they simply had been created willy-nilly. However
column3: when one gets down to assess the figures - I hope I heard the Minister's statement correctly - the savings have been worth €27 million to the Exchequer thus far. That would not keep FÁS going for one week. It is very difficult to know what the equivalent figures are because FÁS has been divided up
column4: but it certainly cost €1 billion per year to run a couple of years ago. Therefore
column5: in the overall context
column6: Members are talking about absolute peanuts. If one is to learn anything from the Irish Water debacle
column7: it is that semi-State bodies and
column8: in particular
column9: State monopolies
column10: are utterly reckless with public money. Does the Minister have further initiatives in mind to ascertain whether other State bodies are indulging in the practices in which Irish Water is indulging? What are his intentions in this regard?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	17	Again
column2: I am proud that there are 169 fewer State bodies than when the Government took office. A total of 141 bodies have been abolished or moved into existing public structures
column3: while 51 old bodies have been streamlined into 23 new bodies. The Government has tackled duplication
column4: streamlined accessibility and accountability and carried out a root and branch analysis. The Deputy will be aware that there will be a demand for new bodies. I have examined the proposals the Deputy has brought to the House during this term and in his own legislation he has proposed the creation of a new broadband commission
column5: a new judicial appointments council
column6: a new public appointments board
column7: a new guardianship board and several more.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	18	I thank the Minister. I could give him a list for the abolition of at least 500 bodies on top of them.
#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	19	That is true.

#ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	20	While the number of bodies I would create is less than half a dozen
column2: I would abolish 500. The Minister is absolutely correct and
column3: of course
column4: I do not suggest there is no need for State bodies. I simply make the point that they duplicate one another in various ways. Will the Minister tell Members about his plans for new directors - an issue which is part of the sickness of new bodies - in the first instance? I have not seen them
column5: which may be my fault. Second
column6: he should give a ballpark figure for how much it costs the State to appoint politically appointed directors
column7: political proteges
column8: to these bodies and how much could be saved by not paying them fees at all?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	21	I strongly agree with the Deputy. Some of the most effective instruments of State policy are State bodies such as IDA Ireland which is envied around the world and Enterprise Ireland. Moreover
column2: the work done by the National Roads Authority and all the other parties involved in maintaining the environment such as the Environmental Protection Agency and so on is really valuable. The Deputy has asked a different question about the Government's new proposals for State boards and a separate question has been tabled on this issue. It will be ground-breaking. I have approved guidelines which will be circulated to my Cabinet colleagues and which I hope to bring before the House as soon as I have them signed off.

column1: #ShaneRoss	unknown-#ShaneRoss-party	unknown-#ShaneRoss-dob	unknown-#ShaneRoss-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	22	Will it be this month?
#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	23	Yes.

#SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	24	On 30 September the Minister issued a press release announcing a revised model for ministerial appointments to State boards. If he is sincere about this
column2: will he provide a legislative basis for the appointments of members to State boards
column3: including commercial and non-commercial semi-State organisations
column4: and not do this merely by way of a press release?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	25	As the Deputy will be aware
column2: the Government recently announced a revised model for ministerial appointments to State boards. In future all appointments to State boards will be advertised openly on the State boards portal
column3: www.stateboards.ie
column4: which
column5: as the Deputy is aware
column6: is operated by the Public Appointments Service
column7: PAS. Officials are preparing overarching guidelines for appointments for approval by the Government
column8: including issues related to diversity. As part of this process
column9: all Departments have been contacted to seek comprehensive details of all State boards under their aegis. The new arrangements also provide that the www.stateboards.ie website
column10: as well as being the sole portal for the receipt of applications for appointments to State boards
column11: also will contain definitive and current information on statutory boards
column12: vacancies that will arise and so on. This material will be published in the near future. It is being gathered and structured across all Departments. A review of these arrangements will be carried out and completed within 18 months to make sure that once it is up and running
column13: it will be effective. It is not envisaged that legislation will be required. However
column14: if the review of the new arrangements
column15: say in 18 months time
column16: determines that it must be put on a statutory basis for any reason
column17: I do not have a closed mind on that option.

column1: #SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	26	I thank the Minister. I note that he commenced his reply by talking about guidelines
column2: but at its conclusion
column3: he stated he had an open mind on whether it required legislation. He will have this opportunity shortly
column4: as I intend to publish legislation to put his press release and the matters about which he spoke on a guideline basis on a statutory footing. Consequently
column5: I hope he will support the legislation as it goes through the House. One issue I seek to have governed by way of legislation rather than guidelines concerns the prospective chairperson appearing before an Oireachtas committee. This should cover other bodies such as regulators and various people with the title of ombudsman or ombudsperson. I note that later on the same day the Minister and I were last here a few weeks ago
column6: he appointed Mrs. Judith Eve as the new chairperson of the Public Appointments Service. Such persons who will have such a central role in monitoring these appointments should have been brought before an Oireachtas committee in order that the people would know who was the chairperson of the body that would vet every other person. That was a slip-up
column7: as although the Minister may not have been required to do this by legislation
column8: he could have done it as a measure of good faith and demonstrate what he was talking about. He also appointed Mr. Liam Sloyan as lottery regulator on the same day. While I am sure both individuals are excellent and outstanding
column9: they should have been brought before an Oireachtas committee.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	27	On the two appointments mentioned by Deputy
column2: the post of lottery regulator was publicly advertised. I had no hand
column3: act or part in determining it as it was the subject of a public appointments decision in the normal way. The post was advertised
column4: applications were received
column5: applicants were interviewed and so on and the best candidate was nominated. In respect of the chairperson of the PAS
column6: I wanted to appoint somebody with experience in the PAS and
column7: as the Deputy is aware
column8: the person I nominated had broad experience
column9: particularly in Northern Ireland
column10: and served in highly distinguished roles. Anybody familiar with the North will know the name and the work involved. However
column11: the objective in broad terms of the entire review system is to have an open system to get the best people and encourage them. I believe and hope the Deputy will be impressed by the guidelines. They will be mandatory for all State boards and there will be no question of not applying them. The idea will be to reach out to people and encourage them. For example
column12: the issue of gender balance must be addressed and there may be panels of people being encouraged to apply
column13: perhaps for more than one State board. Such persons may outline what their skill sets are and may be considered for a number of State boards. The intention is to have much more openness and much greater transparency in how people are appointed. However
column14: it will be necessary to head-hunt some people for specific jobs. Such persons will need to be encouraged
column15: as the Deputy will be aware from his past experience
column16: to apply for critical positions on State boards.

#SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	30	As regulator

#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	33	The Deputy was agin the appointment of the regulator

The National Treasury Management Agency (Amendment) Act 2014 sets out such criteria in relation to the NewERA companies.

#SeanFleming	unknown-#SeanFleming-party	unknown-#SeanFleming-dob	unknown-#SeanFleming-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	36	Will NTMA be exempt from all of this?

#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	37	No. In the semi-State companies

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	38	My question relates to the publication
column2: One Vision Civil Service: The Civil Service Renewal Plan
column3: which is an interesting document. The process by which it has been produced has also been interesting. I am concerned that it does not pass us all by in the busyness of everything else. First
column4: I wanted the Minister
column5: Deputy Howlin
column6: to set out his initial plans for the implementation of what is contained here and then I have a couple of specifics to tease out with him. As he mentioned gender
column7: let me just say that
column8: although 60% of the 35
column9: 000 civil servants are women
column10: only 33% of management grades are filled by women and there is clearly a glass ceiling in the service. It is one of the issues in which I am interested.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	39	I appreciate the Deputy placing a focus on this. We might find an opportunity
column2: perhaps at a committee
column3: to discuss it because this is the culmination of two streams of work. The Civil Service Renewal Plan
column4: which I launched with the Taoiseach last week
column5: is the product of a year-long engagement involving more than 2
column6: 000 staff and stakeholders. It brings together the outcomes of two separate but related streams of work: the work of the independent panel on strengthening Civil Service accountability and performance; and the work of the Civil Service renewal task force
column7: which was a group of civil servants that went around the country talking to civil servants. The renewal plan
column8: approved by Government
column9: aims to build the capability of the Civil Service so it can meet the needs and expectations of the Government and the public into the future. More than 2
column10: 000 staff and stakeholders made formal contributions to the development of the vision "to provide a world-class service to the State and the people of Ireland" and a practical plan with 25 actions will be delivered within the three-year timeline that we have set out. The four areas of focus are: a unified Civil Service - a breakaway from the silos that have caused problems in the past - managing the Civil Service as a single
column11: unified organisation; a professional Civil Service - maximising performance and potential of all civil servants to do their job effectively; a responsive Civil Service - changing our culture
column12: structure and processes so that they become more agile and more flexible to meet the changing environment; and a more open and accountable Civil Service - continuously learning and upskilling. Details of the plan and the two related documents on staff engagement and background data are available at www.per.gov.ie. I note the point the Deputy McDonald made about gender
column13: that
column14: while 60% of the Civil Service overall is women
column15: not enough are managers. We have migrated from 25% to 30% at the top
column16: but we should have equality at the top and we need to have mechanisms to do that.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	40	I agree that this needs a considered discussion
column2: if not by way of debate on the floor of the House
column3: certainly at committee. We need to explore all of these matters. Why did the Minister decide to go for what he calls a "collective responsibility" model rather than
column4: as has been proposed by Professor Rafter and others in the course of their work
column5: a head of Civil Service? I understand Deputy Howlin also envisages an individual spokesperson on behalf of that collective. I am concerned that the immediacy of a person in charge
column6: accountable and answerable gets lost in the Minister's collective model. In terms of organisational capability
column7: which is crucial
column8: the plan talks about - the language is probably a little unfortunate - "Design and implement a light touch
column9: objective review process". The Minister and I would not be so keen on the term "light touch". Could he shed light on those two specific issues?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	41	On the Professor Kevin Rafter group proposal to have a single head
column2: I spoke to him at length. The group looked at the model in Britain and in other countries
column3: and they changed the model a couple of times. Their recommendation was to have either of two options
column4: the first of which was a designated person involving the set up of a new entity with a new Secretary General who would be the head of the Civil Service. Given the capacity - there is 25
column5: 000 civil servants here and 250
column6: 000 in the United Kingdom - I wondered whether that would work all that well. The alternative
column7: and probably preferred
column8: recommendation was to have an existing line Secretary General be head of the Civil Service on a part-time basis
column9: which I did not think worked. My first objective was to have a collective entity because the biggest deficiency
column10: as I have seen looking deeply into it
column11: is the siloing of the Civil Service
column12: that everybody in the Department of Justice and Equality looks at the Department of Justice and Equality and many civil servants go in at a relatively low grade and then migrate
column13: never having moved beyond. It is the same in a lot of line Departments. The first task is to have a much more integrated public service and a collective leadership is a better way of doing that.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	42	I ask that that matter be kept under review. It might well emerge that the Minister is
column2: in fact
column3: correct in that assessment
column4: and if it works
column5: it is fair enough and all is well. However
column6: Deputy Howlin hears my concern. The beauty of having a head of Civil Service is that accountability does not get lost in the collective. I ask that we do not entirely jettison that idea as
column7: perhaps
column8: one for the future. I note the proposals also contain what is termed "an end-to-end review of the disciplinary code". I am curious that we tease that out. I note it makes recommendations in terms of recruitment to more senior managerial posts within the service. That needs to be considered. I am not a believer in privatising
column9: or importing entirely a private sector ethic into the public sector as a way of reforming it. That is wrong-headed. Finally
column10: this report does not deal with the issues of reward and pay within the service
column11: but the Minister will appreciate that manners of rewarding staff are inextricably linked in with the culture of any organisation and the morale of those who serve. We need a commission on pay within the civil and public service. It needs to right the wrong where we currently have at the upper ends excessive levels of pay and at the lower levels paltry wages and rewards for staff
column12: but that may be an issue for another day.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	43	There were a lot of detailed questions that I will not have time to answer and we need a better forum than one which provides a minute to answer these questions. On the first question
column2: I will have an open mind on the leadership. If the other model presents itself in 18 months' time as a better model
column3: I will support that. The review of the discipline code will happen. It is part of what we need to do to ensure that everybody is optimum. We
column4: first
column5: must give real tasks to staff in the Civil Service so they know what they are supposed to do. One cannot state they are not delivering if they do not have a clear understanding of what they are supposed to deliver and the tools to deliver it
column6: in terms of training and skills. That brings me to the other point. Deputy McDonald talks about recruitment. We now have opened general recruitment
column7: but most of the recruitment we had been able to do in the recessionary times was of specialists because there are specialist deficiencies in a number of areas. We have established a new economic advisory group
column8: that has been trained in my Department and now gives economic analysis across all Departments. We have looked at better human resource management by bringing in trained human resource specialists
column9: the same as in procurement
column10: on which my colleague
column11: the Minister of State
column12: will answer questions. Low pay is a real issue. That is why we are establishing a low-pay commission which will look not only at the private sector
column13: but also at the public sector. It will have a broad remit when it is established next year.

column1: #MichaelKitt	unknown-#MichaelKitt-party	unknown-#MichaelKitt-dob	unknown-#MichaelKitt-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	44	Deputy Durkan has the next question
column2: but he is not present.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	45	This question relates to public procurement. The Minister of State will be aware that I have taken a considerable interest in the matter. I am concerned
column2: not least because of a number of very well publicised cases in which there has been evidence and allegations of flagrant breaches of labour law and exploitation of workers. I had cause to speak again yesterday with the workers who are in dispute with JJ Rhatigan in respect of Kishogue Community College in Lucan; that is ongoing. The question is straightforward. What are the plans to ensure full compliance with all legal obligations under labour legislation by companies awarded public contracts with respect to their use of subcontractors
column3: which is the issue at the heart of the JJ Rhatigan dispute?

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	46	I thank the Deputy for her question and I note her ongoing interest in issues of procurement. The main purpose of the EU public procurement regime is to open up the market and ensure the free movement of supplies
column2: services and works within the EU
column3: having regard to Treaty of Rome principles including transparency
column4: proportionality and equal treatment. This is the rationale that shapes the detailed rules and directives governing the regime. Under the current regime and standard forms of contract
column5: there are requirements in place for compliance with legal obligations under labour legislation. For example
column6: clause 2 of the standard form of the public works contract requires the contractor and his or her personnel and subcontractors to comply with all legal requirements. There is a substantial body of legislation that directly or indirectly governs construction activities. However
column7: two key pieces of industry-specific legislation
column8: the Safety
column9: Health and Welfare at Work (Construction) Regulations 2013 and the Building Control Regulations 1997 to 2014
column10: both place considerable responsibility not only on contractors but on all those involved in construction projects
column11: including designers
column12: supervisors and individual workers.  The ultimate sanction for a serious breach of health and safety regulations is a criminal conviction and imprisonment. Compliance with health and safety regulations is separately assessed in a pre-qualification of works contractors
column13: with supporting evidence required to demonstrate that the applicant possesses sufficient resources and is competent to carry out the proposed works. The works requirements
column14: which are a key part of the contract documents
column15: also set out detailed specifications on how regulatory standards are best to be met.  Contractors are required to submit ongoing certification under clause 5.3 of the contract
column16: which deals with pay and conditions of employment
column17: to show that they have complied in full with the requirements of that clause
column18: which covers aspects such as compliance with employment law and deductions for social welfare. Contractors are also required under this clause to maintain records and timesheets in respect of all those engaged on the works.  The new EU rules comprise a suite of three directives that repeal the existing rules governing conduct in procurement across the EU
column19: but the basic architecture of EU procurement will remain intact. I note that I will run out of time. I will come back with a reply to the Deputy's supplementary question. The key message is that I have opened this up to consultation for six weeks. I encourage people to go to the website www.procurement.ie and examine the consultation document. The first question relates to labour law. We are eager to get this right. We get only one opportunity to transpose these directives correctly
column20: and that is why
column21: while consultation was not necessary
column22: I decided it was prudent. Consultation is open until 12 December.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	47	I welcome that consultation
column2: which is indeed prudent. I welcome that at call-for-tender stage a company may be required to specify what part of the contract it does not intend to perform itself but intends to assign to a third party
column3: which is significant. The company will also be required to inform the public purchaser of the names and addresses of such subcontractors
column4: thereby providing a chain of responsibility. These tougher rules on subcontracting are intended to fight what is called "social dumping" and ensure that workers' rights are respected. Equally
column5: it allows that contractors who do not comply may be excluded from bidding. These are very welcome developments. Does the Minister of State accept that we have an issue with social dumping and breaches of labour law in respect of subcontracted work on public contracts?

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	48	I know that the Deputy has highlighted the issue
column2: including during Private Members' time on Fridays. I accept her bona fides in bringing the issue to the House. I have asked the Office for Government Procurement to look into the matter when considering the implementation of the directive. The directive obliges us to give consideration to how we wish to adhere to "applicable obligations" in labour law. While most of the directive is mandatory
column3: each member state has a policy choice on which appropriate measures to adopt to ensure compliance with this obligation. That is the discussion I wish to have between now and 12 December. I am approaching the matter with an open mind. The Minister
column4: Deputy Howlin
column5: undertook significant work during our Presidency of the European Council in getting this through the European Parliament. Considering Ireland's leadership role
column6: I want to ensure Ireland is best in class and that we transpose these directives in a way that ensures flexibility and does not gold-plate them while also addressing the social and labour law issues that we have discussed here and that I am sure we will continue to discuss.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	49	It is very important - I am sure this will be reflected by those with whom the Minister of State consults - that we make the correct policy choices
column2: and in so far as adherence to labour law and the rights of workers are concerned
column3: they need to be watertight and robust. JJ Rhatigan and Company has approximately 50% of school building contracts at construction stage awarded by the Department of Education and Skills. As the Minister of State knows
column4: Unite is in dispute with JJ Rhatigan over the treatment of its members on the site at Kishogue Community College in Lucan. Following a ballot
column5: the workers unanimously decided on industrial action
column6: which commenced on 19 September. They will be in court tomorrow fighting an injunction. JJ Rhatigan operates a complex system of subcontracting under which workers on these public capital contracts have been forced into bogus self-employment with no PRSI
column7: holiday
column8: pension or other entitlements. These workers are effectively earning less than €5 an hour. They have been locked out since 1 September. I know there are obvious limits in what the Minister of State can say and I am not asking him to stray beyond that. However
column9: I ask him to respond as he can to this situation and to make it very clear for those workers and anybody else being exploited in this way that he is aware of the phenomenon and is determined
column10: as I hope we all are
column11: to stamp out these practices. I hope that workers enjoy the Minister of State's support as they try to deal with these exploitative situations.

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	50	The Deputy correctly notes the limitations on what I can say about specific cases. However
column2: I am very happy to say that we have quite a robust suite of labour law. In the procurement area
column3: I want to ensure that in transposing these directives we deal adequately with all of these issues. Obviously the Minister for Jobs
column4: Enterprise and Innovation has overall responsibility for employment rights. The National Employment Rights Authority
column5: NERA
column6: is responsible for enforcing minimum statutory employment rights and entitlements in the State. While we are discussing the issue of subcontractors
column7: the Government has made a decision
column8: led by the Minister
column9: Deputy Howlin
column10: that the Minister of State
column11: Deputy Nash
column12: will work on the implementation of the Construction Contracts Act
column13: which is of serious concern to many subcontractors. I am very proud that this Oireachtas passed the Act
column14: and we expect it to be implemented next year.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	51	We touched on this issue in the course of last week's debate. At that stage I raised with the Minister of State the importance of increasing the access of indigenous small and medium-sized enterprises
column2: including micro-enterprises
column3: to public procurement contracts
column4: in view of the new EU rules agreed in January 2014.

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	52	Some of my prepared reply is the same as I have already outlined
column2: so I will take that as noted regarding the objectives of the EU directives. The Office of Government Procurement is currently exploring policy choices as part of the transposition process. In this context
column3: I have launched a public consultation on the new directives. It is open to everybody - not just specific people - to give their views on how they wish to see these directives transposed
column4: and I urge everybody to do so. We are accepting written submissions up to 12 December. Consideration will be given to the responses received when drafting the statutory instruments to implement the EU rules in national law. Many of the changes in the directives on SME access to
column5: and participation in
column6: the public procurement market were foreshadowed in Circular 10/14 on initiatives to assist SMEs in public procurement
column7: which we have discussed previously. This policy initiative aims to open up opportunities for small businesses to bid for State business by simplifying and streamlining the public procurement process and reducing the administrative burden on businesses wishing to tender for public contracts.  The circular contains guidelines setting out relevant and proportionate financial capacity
column8: turnover and insurance levels for tendering firms and the subdividing of larger contracts into lots to enable SMEs to bid for these opportunities. In addition
column9: the guidelines encourage SMEs to form consortia where they are not of sufficient scale or capability to tender in their own right. The aim is to encourage Irish SMEs
column10: where necessary
column11: to form alliances and networks to ensure they can tender competitively for business. The guidance also encourages suppliers to use fully the e-tender system and to avail of its facilities for registration
column12: e-tendering and automatic alerts for future tendering opportunities. These are facilities which are aimed at easing the administrative burden of suppliers in tendering for public contracts. We have established an SME working group with industry representative bodies
column13: including ISME
column14: IBEC
column15: Small Firms Association
column16: SFA
column17: Chambers Ireland
column18: Construction Industry Federation
column19: CIF
column20: and public sector representation from the office of Government procurement
column21: OGP
column22: the Department of Jobs
column23: Enterprise and Innovation
column24: InterTrade Ireland and Enterprise Ireland. The focus of this group is to develop and monitor SME access to public procurement. This group meets regularly - I am pleased to have met the group recently - and it has broadly welcomed the policy initiatives in the circular. I expect this group to input into the public consultation process. While the circular and its provisions have been broadly welcomed
column25: I am acutely aware
column26: as is the OGP
column27: that the main criticism from many stakeholders is the lack of consistency in the implementation of the circular. If I were to identify one challenge for 2015 it would be to ensure that the SME circular is consistently implemented across the board.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	53	I thank the Minister of State. I appreciate the challenge and I note the consultative phase and also the Meet the Buyer event which will be held shortly. I hope to attend that event. The Minister of State referred in his response to the practice of breaking contracts into lots and making them accessible. He referred to encouraging SMEs and micro-businesses to form consortia to give them the capacity to bid. While on paper this may appear to be a very straightforward proposition
column2: in practice it is failing very many smaller businesses. The Minister of State may be aware that in the stationery sector those companies that bid for stationery business with the State have had an appalling experience in this bidding process and the requirement to create consortia. I am not sure that this particular issue has been terribly well thought out nor am I convinced that the system has had a listening ear to the real experience of businesses. Training has been provided
column3: not least through InterTrade Ireland
column4: which is welcome but we need to get that piece of it right. I encourage the Minister of State to have a particular eye for that issue in the course of his consultation.

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	54	I am pleased to hear that Deputy McDonald hopes to attend the Meet the Buyer event. I have made a point of inviting every Member of the Oireachtas to the event and if the Deputy is not in a position to attend there will be more events. It is very important to allow an opportunity for SMEs to interact first-hand with the public service buyers and for us as policy-makers to see that interaction
column2: to see what is working and what is not working. I accept Deputy McDonald's constructive criticism about consortia; it is a criticism I have heard from the representative bodies. I refer again to the consultation process which will provide an opportunity to look at what is working and what is not working
column3: to look at what we want to achieve from these directives. All too often EU directives can be regarded as negative or challenging measures but in my view we must seize them as an opportunity. The Deputy correctly said that we are looking at upskilling SMEs by providing training sessions so that they are ready to engage in procurement. It is in the interests of the entire Irish economy that we get more SMEs availing of and winning public procurement contracts.

column1: #MaryLouMcDonald	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-party	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-dob	unknown-#MaryLouMcDonald-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	55	I hope the consultation period will be successful. A number of issues were raised within the stationery sector
column2: including concerns to do with quality levels and the health and safety standards required in respect of stationery provided to schools
column3: including primary schools. The sector has brought these issues to the attention of some of the Minister of State's colleagues. I ask that when those observations come back about the real experience of those involved in any sector that they will not be brushed off or dismissed. It is my view that the health and safety and quality issues as well as some of the predatory practices
column4: perhaps
column5: by others outside of the State who tender for this business and who are bigger operators
column6: are very real concerns. I ask the Minister of State to consider those very carefully because it is a case of getting it right and as he says
column7: ensuring that as many indigenous Irish SMEs and micro-businesses can legitimately and fairly win as many contracts as possible.

column1: #SimonHarris	unknown-#SimonHarris-party	unknown-#SimonHarris-dob	unknown-#SimonHarris-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	56	I agree with much of what the Deputy says and she is correct. Aside from capital projects the State spends about €23 million a day on purchasing goods and services. It is a very significant contribution to the domestic economy and to the flow of money around the domestic economy. There is also an issue with SMEs needing to know that the public procurement process is open to them. We want them to become involved. It is a little like exporting in the days of the Celtic tiger when exporting was viewed as something only done by larger companies. There has been a cultural shift and a change in the mindset and many smaller businesses are exporting successfully. We need to get to that point with regard to procurement where the procurement process is open to everyone in every town and village and where we provide all the supports. I agree we need to achieve value for money and we have very ambitious savings targets. However
column2: we have previously debated the point that value for money is not always a case of the bottom line; it comprises a formula that is more complex than just considering the bottom line. That is the balance we need to achieve. I hope we get it right most of the time - I am not saying we get it right all the time - and hopefully this consultation process will tease out these issues.

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	57	I wish to ask the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform whether he will reduce the very high level of temporary staffing across the public sector by converting such posts to permanent jobs.

#BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	58	I thank the Deputy for his question. In my role as Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform
column2: I have overarching responsibility for recruitment to the Civil Service. All such recruitment is governed by the Public Service (Management and Recruitment) Act 2004. Under the Act
column3: the method of appointment to a permanent Civil Service post is as a result of being successful in a competition run by the Public Appointments Service or by another licence-holder such as the head of a Department or office. Selection processes are open to all eligible applicants who meet minimum entry criteria. In the main
column4: vacancies in the Civil Service are filled on a permanent basis. However
column5: temporary vacancies arise from time to time to cover such absences as maternity leave or shorter working year and where a permanent vacancy will not exist and a job needs to be done for a finite period of time. Temporary clerical officer positions in the Civil Service are filled by an annual competition conducted by PAS which is usually advertised in February of each year. It is a matter for human resource units in all Departments and agencies to have procedures in place for dealing with the recruitment and employment of fixed-term employees and the management of their contracts. My Department issues guidelines
column6: entitled Best Practice for the Recruitment and Management of Fixed-term Employees in the Irish Civil Service
column7: which are revised from time to time. The most recent version issued in April 2014 and took account of changes arising as a result of the single pension scheme and the Haddington Road agreement. The guidelines can be found on my Department's website. PeoplePoint
column8: the Civil Service human resources and pensions shared service centre
column9: became operational in March 2013 and brings together shared HR and pension processes and systems. There are now over 24
column10: 000 employees availing of PeoplePoint services across 20 Departments and offices. The use of contract staff for these posts was necessary to ensure that business needs were met and as a temporary response to the demands of this new service. Plans are progressing to replace those temporary clerical officers with permanent staff. In June of this year PAS advertised a recruitment competition to fill permanent clerical officer positions in the Civil Service and public service. In excess of 28
column11: 000 applications were received and the first successful applicants are now being offered appointments in line with demand to fill vacancies across the Civil Service and the public service. Decisions on the filling of posts
column12: permanent or otherwise
column13: in other public service bodies are a matter for the employing bodies in the context of their business needs.

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	59	There is an inordinate number of temporary contract workers in the public sector
column2: in particular
column3: as a consequence of the recruitment embargo and people were brought in on very short-term contracts.These contracts were renewed one after the other and many had to resort to the courts to have the State implement the law to give them fixity of tenure. If we look at the Department of Education and Skills
column4: we will see the matter involves 935 primary school teachers and 2
column5: 618 post-primary school teachers
column6: not all of whom are replacing teachers on maternity leave and so on. Almost 200 staff have been employed on temporary contracts in PeoplePoint; some of whom have been in the Department for years; were promised a confined establishment competition in which they could hope to move to a permanent position and now find themselves thrown into the mix with 29
column7: 000 other applicants to join the public sector generally. This is highly unfair. They were made a promise and I would like to know what the Minister will do about it.

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	60	In general
column2: I am far happier to have permanent appointments where there is a permanent job to be filled. That is what we are going to migrate to. We certainly had difficulties in filling positions that were needed during the time there were restrictions on recruitment. Some staff were recruited on a short-term basis. I have a difficulty. I want permanent staff in PeoplePoint
column3: but I must allow others to apply for jobs. I cannot simply say those who have been there on a temporary basis will automatically be given all of the positions. That would not be fair to others who want to apply for them. As far as is practicable
column4: staff can apply and will be facilitated. They will have an advantage in their applications because they already have the skills required. I am aware that there are people who have applied and have not met the recruitment criteria for the jobs being created within PeoplePoint on a permanent basis. I encourage people to keep going in order that everybody will have an equal opportunity to secure jobs
column5: as opposed to me saying this discrete section will have precedence over all others.

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	61	Of course
column2: we want people to have proper decent jobs in the public sector with proper pensions and conditions
column3: but that has been made far more difficult by the fact that the Government and the previous Administration did not replace up to 30
column4: 000 public sector workers. Does the Minister not see the difficulty of staff in PeoplePoint with up to two years experience who hope to be made permanent but who might now face the dole? It is not fair to regard them as complete outsiders competing with others applying for the first time. Surely it is a matter of justice. I ask the Minister to give an assurance that the people concerned will move to permanent positions. What is the position of those with contracts of indefinite duration who as a result of threatening legal action had inferior conditions under which they were employed on temporary contracts in being made permanent?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	62	As PeoplePoint became operational in March 2013
column2: staff have not been there for years. I take account of the point made by the Deputy that we must have some consideration for those who are doing the job on a temporary contract
column3: some of whom have had that contract rolled over because it is only an annual contract. I do not know whether it is the Deputy's position that they should automatically be made permanent and that people elsewhere in the Civil Service or those not employed in it but who would like to seek a clerical officer position should be excluded from applying for these jobs. On balance
column4: we should have an open competition to fill all jobs
column5: but those already there have an advantage inasmuch as they have a proven track record of being able to do the job. That is the better way to go.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	63	In his expenditure statement the Minister mentioned the fact that the Civil Service leadership in Departments and agencies would have much more autonomy in recruiting staff. I also note that in the interesting report
column2: Vision One
column3: which was launched recently by the Minister
column4: action 18 also refers to developing the capacity of local managers to develop or recruit their own staff. How is this working out? The Minister mentioned recruitment in 2014. What are the plans for 2015
column5: given the fact that he and the previous Government have presided over the slashing of the public service by something like 10% and the fact that 73% of staff in the Civil Service are aged over 40 years and that only 4% are under 30?

column1: #BrendanHowlin	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-party	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-dob	unknown-#BrendanHowlin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	64	The Deputy used pejorative words like "slashing". The bottom line is that if every organisation of State was to do things more effectively and efficiently - which it can do - we would produce much more for less by transforming the way we provide services. I know that the Deputy would not be so backward as to think we could not modernise the Civil Service or that we should stay in a frozen state. As I announced on budget day last month
column2: I will seek to put in place new arrangements to replace the moratorium on recruitment and promotion in the public service from 2015 onwards. This will be subject to the issuance of formal delegated sanction by my Department to all other Departments and offices in return for agreed commitments by them to manage staff resources within agreed pay ceilings and meet ongoing reform and efficiency objectives. Under the new arrangements which my Department has begun to discuss in detail with the other Departments
column3: sectoral managers will be incentivised to make further savings. Where these are achieved - for example
column4: by recasting the grade mix or reassigning duties or introducing more efficient work practices
column5: all of which are normal ways of doing business - such savings can be reinvested in expanding services to meet increased demand
column6: including hiring more staff
column7: where appropriate. There will be restrictions and controls to prevent unwarranted grade drift and unsustainable recruitment and
column8: of course
column9: recruitment will be carried by the Public Appointments Service in the normal way and open to open competition.  The Deputy will be aware that the moratorium was first introduced as an emergency measure in response to the fiscal crisis that struck the public finances under the last Administration and as a policy instrument
column10: it has made an important contribution on two fronts. First
column11: it has helpedto deliver more than €3 billion in Exchequer pay bill savings
column12: which is a huge contribution to the repairing of the public finances. Second
column13: since 2011 in particular
column14: it has served to help drive reform across the public service
column15: underpinning programmes to introduce new and more efficient ways of delivering public services across the system.  We have produced a number of reform plans with which the Deputy is familiar. It is transforming the way the State deals with citizens
column16: making it much more transparent
column17: open and
column18: I hope
column19: efficient.

column1: Additional information not given on the floor of the House.
Nonetheless
column2: in the course of framing the second public service reform plan which I launched at the beginning of the year it became clear to me that an emergency measure such as the moratorium was not conducive to long-term
column3: sustainable reform and service provision. It is simply not something that any major organisation can or should wish to sustain over a long period
column4: which is why the new reform plan contained a commitment to introduce more flexibility at the operational level. In the context of the budget
column5: therefore
column6: having regard to our much improved fiscal position which allowed the Government to bring an end to spending cuts
column7: I decided to accelerate implementation of the reform commitment and work towards introducing the new arrangements early next year.  This change in policy is not about giving a blanket sanction for widespread recruitment or promotion across the public service
column8: nor does it signal an end to the efficiency drive that has defined public service reform in the past few years; rather
column9: it is about giving those who are best placed - front-line managers - a degree of freedom in the management of staff resources to meet the demands they face. With this comes responsibility to make the right decisions
column10: continue to implement reform and continue to achieve efficiency gains. That requirement will be reflected in the terms and conditions of the sanction being finalised. As outlined in the reform plan
column11: the policy objective in this change of approach is twofold: to continue to contain the cost of delivering public services at affordable and sustainable levels in the medium term; and to allow the public service to respond and adapt quickly to the needs of the citizen.  Regarding recruitment to the Civil Service
column12: about which the Deputy asks specifically
column13: the Public Appointment Service has begun a number of open competitions
column14: including at clerical and graduate grades. Some more will follow in 2015
column15: with the dual aim of bringing new people and new skills into the public service and addressing any imbalance which may have developed during the operation of the moratorium. The competitions run by the Public Appointment Service are advertised nationally and open to all suitably qualified candidates.

column1: #TommyBroughan	unknown-#TommyBroughan-party	unknown-#TommyBroughan-dob	unknown-#TommyBroughan-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-11-06 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	65	In respect of local management

column8: has the Minister settled on a modern
